docs.text:
.steps-title { float: left; width: 25%; margin-bottom: 20px; }
.steps-title > p { font-weight: bold; font-size: 150%; }
.steps-content { float: left; width: 74%; margin-bottom: 20px; }
.clear { clear: both; }
.center { text-align: center; }
.social { text-align: center; }




Welcome to Datapalooza!


Datapalooza is a 3 day immersive experience for the data science community.
Join a diverse community of data professionals, listen to some great music and create inspirational data products.


Learn


Take the 
Spark Fundamentals
 course and the

Data Scientist Workbench Tutorial

on Big Data University.


Run Spark


Login into your 
Data Scientist Workbench
 account to have a Spark runtime immediately available for you!


Download the Mobile App from an IOS or Android App Store




All attendees, speakers, mentors and staff emails have been entered into the system and have create accounts for you.


Simply log-in with your emails address and the password datapalooza


Build your perfect agenda


You can select sessions you want to attended by day, by track, and by competency


Add your sessions to your calendar


Take notes within the app!


Make sure you check in to work towards datapalooza top Data Science, Data Engineering, and Data App Development badges


Stay connected with other attendees, speakers and mentors
docs.title: First Steps

docs.text:
Slack
 is an
awesome platform for team communication and it's our tool of
choice for this hackathon. All the communication will flow
through Slack!


You have been sent an invitation for this hackathon's

Slack team
.
In case you haven't received it, please find an organizer.


You can use Slack from your Web browser, but we

strongly recommend
 that you the native apps:




Mac OS


Windows


iOS


Android

Session


Materials










Caltrain Rider: A Complete Data Product

https://github.com/muvr

https://github.com/muvr

https://github.com/muvr






NLP Enriched Product Review


https://github.com/AlchemyAPI/reviewRecipe






Search by Selfie: a Spark Facial Recognition Algorithm


https://github.com/hackspark/SearchBySelfie/blob/master/photoSearchApp.ipynb

docs.text:
Overview


Data Scientist Workbench aims to be your one-stop shop for
data science tools. At this time, it includes Jupyter notebooks and Zeppelin notebooks enabled with Spark integration, as well as R Studio IDE and OpenRefine. You can use notebooks to develop and run data science projects, as well visualize, document and present your analysis.








For more information, take the 
Data Scientist Workbench Tutorial
 on Big Data University.


Requesting your own Data Scientist Workbench


Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the big blue button. After completing the registration, you will receive an e-mail with instructions.


Hello World


To get a feel of how the Data Scientist Notebooks work with Scala and Spark, follow the steps below to load a "Hello World" notebook along with its sample data.







Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.




Use the search bar to import the following file and notebook.
    

    

    

    






Notebook:
  
https://share.knowledgeanyhow.org/#/api/v1/workbench/10.114.214.68/shares/sHbSUP0luy1xE2q/Scala%20and%20Spark%20in%2015%20minutes.ipynb






Data:

https://share.knowledgeanyhow.org/#/api/v1/workbench/10.114.214.68/shares/t9LwxWg0EkWKMYX/2015.csv










Follow the notebook!
    

    

    

    






For more details on sharing data and notebooks, check 
this guide
.
docs.title: Data Scientist Workbench

docs.text:
Data Scientist Workbench aims to be your one-stop shop for
data science tools. At this time, it includes Jupyter notebooks and Zeppelin notebooks enabled with Spark integration, as well as R Studio IDE and OpenRefine. You can use notebooks to develop and run data science projects, as well visualize, document and present your analysis.     For more information, take the  Data Scientist Workbench Tutorial  on Big Data University.

docs.text:
Sample Data - San Francisco


We are providing an example data set to get you started, but we encourage you to use use your own. You can download it in the link below.


http://bit.ly/SFHackData


Next, you'll probably want to extract the 
zip
 file and 
upload the 
csv
 files to your workbench
.
docs.title: Download Sample Data

Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.




Use the search bar to import the following notebooks.
    

    

    

    






Weather Data Preparation:
  
https://share.knowledgeanyhow.org/#/api/v1/workbench/10.114.214.68/shares/L9ftHk00qCVG8qL/Weather%20Data%20Preparation%20v2.ipynb






Weather Data Analysis and Visualization:
  
https://share.knowledgeanyhow.org/#/api/v1/workbench/10.114.214.68/shares/9tDhX5RIIQLIKcB/Weather%20Data%20Analysis%20Visualization%20v2.ipynb










You can get the 
API key
 
here
.






Follow the notebooks!
    

    

    

    






For more details on sharing data and notebooks, check 
this guide
.
docs.title: Analyzing Weather Data

docs.text:
Sharing data and notebooks can be very useful for team collaboration.


Exporting Data and Notebooks




Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.


Find the file or notebook you want to share, and click the twistie (
) to the left of it.




Click the 
share
 button (
).
    

    

    

    






Click the 
Show Link
 link to get the link to the shared notebook.




Send this link to the person you're sharing the file or notebook with.




Importing Data and Notebooks




Copy the link of the file or notebook you want to import (from step 5 above).


Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.




Paste the link in the text field at the top right corner of the page.
    

    

    

    






Hit 
Enter
 to import the file or notebook.
docs.title: Sharing Data and Notebooks

docs.text:
Go to  Data Scientist Workbench  and click the  My Notebooks  menu.  Find the file or notebook you want to share, and click the twistie ( ) to the left of it.   Click the  share  button ( ).
     
     
     
        Click the  Show Link  link to get the link to the shared notebook.   Send this link to the person you're sharing the file or notebook with.
docs.title: Exporting Data and Notebooks

docs.text:
Copy the link of the file or notebook you want to import (from step 5 above).  Go to  Data Scientist Workbench  and click the  My Notebooks  menu.   Paste the link in the text field at the top right corner of the page.
     
     
     
        Hit  Enter  to import the file or notebook.
docs.title: Importing Data and Notebooks

docs.text:
To data into your Data Scientist Workbench, all you have to do is:




Go to 
Data Scientist Workbench
 and click the 
My Notebooks
 menu.


Drag the files you want to load from your computer and drop them on DSW.




Note:
 There is no upload progress indication. If you're trying to upload a large file, it might take a few minutes for the upload to complete and the file show up in "Recent Data".
docs.title: Load Data into DSW

docs.text:
R


Use 
install.packages()
 in a R notebook, as shown in the example below.


install.packages(
yaml
, repos=
http://cran.stat.ucla.edu
)




Python


Open a Python notebook and use 
pip
 to install Python packages, as shown below.


!pip install vincent




Scala


Adding new JARs is not officially supported at this time.
docs.title: Install Libraries

docs.title: Scala

docs.text:
We'll use GitHub


Ensure your team is 
registered
!






Set Up Git






Initialize your team's repository by:






Creating a new repository:


  echo "# 
REPOSITORY_NAME
" 
 README.md
  git init
  git add README.md
  git commit -m "first commit"
  git remote add origin git@github.com:hacktheweather/
REPOSITORY_NAME
.git
  git push -u origin master







Or push an existing one:


  git remote add origin git@github.com:hacktheweather/
REPOSITORY_NAME
.git
  git push -u origin master











Download your team's notebooks from DSW (
.ipynb
) to your machine.
  

  

  

  






Commit and push notebooks and sample data to GitHub.
docs.title: Submit your Code
